title: The Heart of a Steward
sub_title: More Than Just a Job: A Lesson in Faithful Stewardship
devotional:
Old Man Fitzwilliam, a caretaker of the grand estate 'Oakhaven,' was known for his meticulous nature. He nurtured the gardens with tireless dedication, ensuring every rose bloomed vibrantly, every tree stood tall and strong. Oakhaven was not his; he was merely a steward, yet he treated it as if it were his own, laboring with a passion that bewildered many.

One autumn, a fierce storm swept through the land. Many trees fell, rose bushes were uprooted, and the once pristine gardens of Oakhaven lay in ruins. The owner of the estate, a wealthy businessman, surveyed the damage with a shrug. 'It's just property,' he said. 'We'll hire someone to clear it up, plant a few new things. No big deal.'

But Old Man Fitzwilliam was heartbroken. He wandered through the wreckage, carefully collecting broken branches, gently righting overturned plants, his eyes filled with sorrow. The businessman scoffed, 'Why bother, Fitzwilliam? It's not your place to care so much. It's just a job.'

Fitzwilliam looked up, his face etched with conviction. 'It is my job, sir, but it is also my calling. God has entrusted me with this place, with these gardens. It is my responsibility to care for them, to nurture them, to protect them, not because they are mine, but because they are His.'

The story of Old Man Fitzwilliam reminds us that stewardship is not merely about managing resources; it is about recognizing that everything we have – our talents, our time, our possessions – is a gift from God, entrusted to us for a purpose. We are called to be faithful stewards, not owners, using what we have been given to honor God and bless others. This extends to the earth itself, which we must steward responsibly, always mindful that it is borrowed from our children.
image_description: A sprawling, well-manicured garden following a storm, with fallen leaves scattered on the ground, creating a carpet of autumn colors and a single wheelbarrow with gardening tools.
insights: The parable of the talents in Matthew 25:14-30 underscores the importance of active stewardship. The master entrusted his servants with varying amounts of talents (money), expecting them to invest and increase them. The servant who buried his talent was condemned, not for losing it, but for failing to use it. This highlights that stewardship is not passive; it requires diligence, creativity, and a willingness to take risks for God's glory. Similarly, 1 Peter 4:10 states, 'Each of you should use whatever gift you have received to serve others, as faithful stewards of God’s grace in its various forms' (NIV).
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for entrusting me with the gifts and resources I have. Forgive me for the times I have been careless or selfish with what you have given me. Help me to see myself as a steward, responsible for using my talents, time, and possessions to honor you and bless others. Give me the wisdom and courage to invest my life in ways that will have a lasting impact for your kingdom. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: What gifts and resources has God entrusted to you? How are you currently using them to honor Him and bless others? What changes can you make to be a more faithful steward of what you have been given? How can you improve your stewardship of the Earth's resources, remembering they are not ours to spoil?
